title.narrative: World Bank Group Partnership Fund for the SDGs

description.narrative:
The World Bank Group (WBG) has together with Sida identified the need for a mechanism that can enable investments into strategic, high-impact and low-cost SDG 17 initiatives implemented by WBG staff in partnership with non-Bank actors. To respond to this need, the WBG has in cooperation with Sida developed a concept note to launch a Bank-executed, multi-donor trust fund called "The World Bank Group Partnership Fund for the SDGs". As the first donor committing to the fund, Sida is allocating SEK 63,000,000 for 2018 - 2019 for the purpose and intending to allocate an additional SEK 54,000,000 during 2020 - 2022.
The overall purpose of the Partnership Fund is to target financing gaps and build operational capacity for Bank Group initiatives that promote the means of implementation for achieving the SDGs, including SDG data, research generation, new tools and methodologies, capacity-building, institutional strengthening and multi-stakeholder partnerships. Such initiatives often require a comparatively smaller financial commitment but are often overlooked as they do not necessarily align with the core mandate for other funding sources linked to specific themes or sectors. The funding will help complement scarce Bank budget resources for activities that are otherwise often left unfunded within regular operational streams. The Fund will act as a catalyst to spark further investment in the SDGs by encouraging WBG projects in support of SDG 17.
The WBG is approaching other potential donors and expect several of them to make contributions as the fund is launched.

Världsbanken har i dialog med Sida utvecklat en givargemensam partnerskapsfond med fokus på genomförandet av SDG 17 och främja partnerskap. Fonden svarar upp mot ett identifierat behov av finansiering för små, men strategiska initiativ för att informera policyskapare i syfte att generera stor effekt för fattigdomsbekämpning och hållbarhet.
Initiativet uppstod då Världsbanken vid flera tillfällen efterfrågat mindre stöd från Sida för olika ändamål i genomförandet och exekutionen av Agenda 2030 och genomförandet av de hållbara målen. Fonden förväntas att möta denna efterfrågan och samla olika insatser för stöd till genomförandet på ett ställe för institutionellt kunskapsuppbyggande, möjlighet för duplicering av goda projekt, erfarenheter och idéer, peer-to peer learning och ekonomiska skalfördelar i genomförande.
Sida har fört nära dialog med Världsbanken och påverkat fondens utveckling till att även inkludera aktörer utanför Världsbanksgruppen och Världsbanksgruppen inkom med en formell förfrågan (Concept Note) i april 2018, vilken sedan har utvecklats vidare till den nu föreslagna fonden. Genom en givargemensam fond kring medel för genomförande av Agenda 2030 och hållbarhetsmålen (SDGs) kommer fonden ha en samlande funktion för kunskapsdrivna instrument som är centrala för förstärka hållbarhet i dess tre dimensioner i Agenda 2030.
Sida är den första givaren till fonden och åtagit sig att bidra med SEK 63 000 000 under perioden 2018 - 2019. Sida har för avsikt att allokera ytterligare SEK 54 000 000 för perioden 2020 - 2022.
Fondens syfte är att stärka kapacitets- och kunskapsutveckling, metodutveckling, innovation, data och statistik och fattigdomsanalys i Bankgruppens arbete med Agenda 2030. Fonden bedöms vara ett kostnadseffektivt instrument som samlar mindre och flexibla initiativ som annars inte ryms inom Världsbanksgruppens större program, eller givarens begränsningar kring administration. Den givargemensamma fonden är utformad för att komplettera andra Agenda 2030-fonder inom FN som kanaliserar medel till genomförande på landnivå. Fonden avser att främja ett integrerat arbetssätt inom Världsbanksgruppen, nya metoder inom Världsbanken som i partnerskap med andra aktörer och där skapa synergier mellan olika program och bidra till ett ökat globalt lärande.
Världsbanksgruppen är i dialog med andra potentiella givare och har goda förhoppningar om allokeringar när fonden är lanserad. Detta är tillsammans med projektets utveckling av spridande av projektkunskap och lärande i land-till-land och regionala dimensioner av särskilt intresse för Sida att följa i dialog med Världsbanksgruppen (Detta gäller även FN och VBGs samverkan inom implementeringen av de hållbara målen).

description.narrative: The SDG Fund is active in all six World Bank Group regions and supports 23 activities with over 30 country pilots and more than 100 partnerships mobilized. Early results are already being reported. One of the early activities of the SDG Fund was to support the Disability and Inclusion team to provide training on disability data for key national stakeholders, collecting and using disability-disaggregated data across the WBG project cycle, and supporting client countries to design projects that address and include persons with disabilities. A cornerstone of IDA19, disability inclusiveness is critical in the WB’s work, with this activity piloted in Nigeria and Ghana. Another of the SDG Fund’s activities is the Refugee Investment and Matchmaking Platform. The Platform helped Jordanian companies close more than 25 business deals and create more than 1,200 new jobs; secured USD $50 Million dollars in commitments for refugee-focused investments; and produced a Charter of Good Practice, endorsed by more than 200 partners, to promote great private sector engagement in support of refugees around the world. Sida acknowledges that the Fund already (March 2020) has proven its importance as an accelerator for the achievement of the SDGs and that the current portfolio shows a great variety of highly important and powerful projects and engagements with a broad variety of partners for this purpose. Sida can see that many of the SDGs are already covered by the activities and that the fund fulfils its purpose to deliver and enhance funding for high-level impact with small scale grants for data, capacity development partnership and innovation. The broadness and variety of different partnerships within the portfolio is relevant and is enabling partnerships within the World Bank Group, between WB and UN and with WB and other stakeholders. Looking into the portfolio one can see that the current projects and initiatives are set up to deliver against important development areas, which all are of great interest for Sida and aligned with Sidas policies and guiding principles. The SDG Fund’s portfolio includes a good thematic and geographic mix of projects, that address key cross-cutting issues related to gender, inclusion and poverty reduction. Examples of this are partnership-building activities in gender and gender mainstreaming, working against gender-based violence (GBV), facilitating data- collection, analysis and dissemination for development, mobilizing engagement from the private sector in both implementation and funding, working on employment with refugees and migration, integrating the issue of disabilities in project implementation and social protection among several other highly relevant areas (also see annex 2, SDG Fund Project List_Feb2020). The SDG Fund needs further to take the critical role of partnerships in the SDG Fund to be brought more to the forefront in the Funds communication both internally and when talking to new partners as partnerships create innovation. Sida and WBG assessed at an early stage, during project preparation phase, that there are several other donors with a strong commitment to Agenda 2030, capacity development and data and data analyses that could contribute to the SDG Fund and Sida assessed then the risk of Sweden being to only donor as low to medium. Sida assessed then that there were several donors with strong commitment to Agenda 2030 and capacity development, analyses and data that could contribute. However, after one year there is only one other donor, South Korea, that contributes to the fund together with Hyundai Steel a South Korean company and Sida needs to monitor the progress of the fund to attract more attention and funding from other donors to secure further impact, sustainability and ownership. With this given, Sida needs to assess the risk of still being the (primarily) single donor since the intention from the set-up of the fund was different. The progress of the Funds ability to attract more funding from other donors is crucial for Sidas future engagement in the Fund. Initially the funding from Sida was set to be for a 5 year period 2018-2022, but the internal budgetary planning only made it possible to decide for the first two years directly (current agreement for 2018-2019) and that a decision was going to be made on the remaining funds (years 2020-2022) in 2020. Since the SDG Fund has moved quickly in mobilizing support for the World Bank Group’s work towards the SDGs, it’s important for the Fund to keep the momentum going entering the Decade of Action to deliver on the Goals by 2030. As the SDG Fund outlines its strategy for the next phase of critical work, the Fund applies to Sida for funding support to ensure continued operations through 2022. Results from 2020 with responses to the Covid 19 Pandemic. During 2020 the Fund has identified the effects that COVID-19 have on the poor and vulnerable, who are at risk of being left further behind. The Funds important work on designing and implementing essential policies and programs to continuously lift the poorest out of poverty and now the implications of Covid 19, is critical, as the Bank/Fun states and Sida appreciate this work strongly. The Funds work to support developing countries to reset their priorities and reallocate resources to meet immediate needs is much appreciated. And also, as the Bank/th Fund states: The 2030 Agenda can serve as a valuable and effective framework for countries to build back stronger and better. Sida also appreciate the Funds swift and adaptive approach in dealing with the Covid 19 pandemic and its implications on the Funds activities and future results: The fund operates in a flexible and adaptable way to adjust and use resources in a way that prevents setbacks and derailment of efforts on the way to yielding results for sustainability goals and long-term sustainable development. The annual report gives many examples of the Funds achievements, such as the result sin the Investment Matchmaking Platform for Refugee Communities, that has contributed to the finalisation of 51 business transactions, 21 of which are due to companies adjusting production to address COVID19 needs, and has contributed to 156 MUSD in investments in Jordan-based businesses which resulted in the creation of 1770 new jobs. Also worth mentioning is the work with the ‘Enabling Access to Credit for Marginalized Groups through Alternative Data for Credit Reporting’ initiative were progress was significantly impacted by COVID-19 and the team has been working with pilot leaders during the lockdown to minimize the delays that will arise due to the pandemic. This through engaging with pilot leaders to identify ways alternative data and new models to contribute to policy formulation and credit granting during the recovery phases. Sida looks forward on following the development of the SDG Atlas by highlighting trends, comparisons, and measurement issues related to the SDGs also with a response to COVID-19. The 2020 Vision: A Data-Driven Exploration of SDG Monitoring and Implementation project will through the work on the SDG Atlas strengthen linkages between COVID-19 and SDG 1, SDG 3, SDG 4, and SDG 16 and produce Field Notes, case studies exploring the connections between SDG goals and World Bank operations, and selected stories on the impact of the pandemic. The activities on Qualitative and Interactive Mapping of Gender-Based Violence Service Providers and COMMITTING TO DISABILITY-INCLUSIVE DEVELOPMENT both delivers to WBGs commitment toward greater shared prosperity by increasing inclusion of marginalized and vulnerable groups. With the COVID-19 pandemic that currently continues to have wide-reaching impacts across all countries, and in developing countries in particular, working with marginalized groups such as persons with disabilities and with gender implications such as GBV is of highest importance. Sida appreciates that the Fund can contribute to have a positive effect on groups of exposed and vulnerable individuals.
